Award.AwardTitle: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2015
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2015, Research Using Biological Collections. The fellowship supports a research and training plan for the Fellow to take transformative approaches to grand challenges in biology that employ biological collections in highly innovative ways. The title of the research plan for this fellowship to Rachael Bay is "Elucidating population history and migration patterns of yellow warblers through DNA analysis." The host institution for this fellowship is the University of California Los Angeles, and the sponsoring scientist is Dr. Thomas Smith.

The fellowship research uses cutting-edge DNA sequencing technology to elucidate migration patterns of the yellow warbler and measure changes in population size and structure over time. Understanding the distribution of genetic diversity across space and time helps explain animal movement and evolutionary capacity, both important considerations in species conservation. The research capitalizes on the wealth of information available through genomic sequencing and the depth provided by extensive biological collections. The yellow warbler has experienced population declines, likely due to habitat fragmentation and destruction. Using DNA extracted from an extensive feather collection housed at the Center for Tropical Research at UCLA permits measurement of migratory connectivity which, although important for predicting the broader impacts of local disturbance, is difficult to measure using traditional non-genetic methods. In addition, using museum specimens from the Natural History Museum of Los Angeles County and the Museum of Vertebrate Zoology at the University of California at Berkeley, changes in population structure and genetic diversity over time are being measured, allowing direct measurement of the evolutionary consequences of habitat destruction and development and informaing conservation decisions.

Training goals include gaining new skills in emerging genomic techniques and the use of collections samples to add a temporal depth not available through sampling existing populations. Educational outreach involves training for undergraduate researchers as well public outreach through the Audubon Society and similar groups. Finally, the project itself has far-reaching conservation implications. Understanding the distribution of genetic diversity and how it has changed along with habitat loss and fragmentation helps inform management plans, for example by conserving habitat for evolutionarily important lineages or preserving wildlife corridors between isolated populations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Rapid environmental shifts brought on by anthropogenic climate change negatively impact organisms and ecosystems globally. Recent research has suggested that evolutionary adaptation might mitigate the negative impacts of climate change, but the rate and limits of adaptation remain unclear. In migratory animals, an additional challenge is to understand where organisms live across their entire life cycle. For my NSF postdoctoral research project, I examined migration and climate adaptation in the migratory songbird Yellow Warbler, answering the following questions: 1) Which populations are most likely to adapt to ongoing climate change and 2) Where do Yellow Warbler breeding populations spend the wintering season. 

Which populations are most likely to adapt to ongoing climate change?

During the breeding season, Yellow Warblers are broadly distributed across North America, which means they inhabit a wide range of climates from the droughts of California to the wet Pacific Northwest. Using genome sequencing, I identified variation in genes that mirrored climate patterns across the breeding range. I found the precipitation, rather than temperature, was more important in driving adaptation. I also found particular genes that appeared to be important in this adaptation, including some that have previously been connected with migration patterns in birds.

To determine which populations were most likely to adapt to ongoing climate change, I used projections of future climates provided by the IPCC to determine how much genome evolution would be required to track future environmental shifts, a measure I called “genomic vulnerability”. I then compared this with long-term survey data and found that populations with high genomic vulnerability had experienced population declines since 1966. This suggests that these populations have already been negatively impacted by climate change and that those impacts are likely to become more severe as climate change continues. 

Where do Yellow Warbler breeding populations spend the wintering season? 

In order to form effective conservation plans, it’s important to know where vulnerable populations spend the wintering season. Yellow Warblers winter across Central America and some regions of South America. Using genomic data, I identified five distinct breeding populations across North America. I then assigned birds caught on the wintering grounds back to these breeding populations. I found broad scale mixing across the wintering grounds; all five breeding populations were distributed broadly across Central America. The exception to this was the eastern breeding population – birds that bred on the east coast of the US and Canada wintered exclusively in South America. Understanding these connections will help create effective conservation management plans across the full life cycle of the species.
